Dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed in a “savage” pre-planned murder at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan alleged on Tuesday as he demanded answers from Riyadh.

“We have significant signs that this was not something that happened instantaneously, spontaneously,” Mr Erdogan said in speech to members of his parliamentary party. “Khashoggi was murdered in a ferocious manner.”

The Turkish president raised a series of questions, but stopped short of directly accusing the Saudi leadership of murder.

HK 3Q18 system loan growth could be negative qoq. In
2017, HSBC Asia loan growth was 17pct; in 2018E, we forecasts 6pct. Slower HK loan growth reflects the slowdown in China, a depreciating RMB and trade war concerns. Consensus loan growth 2019-22, and as a result NII, is too high.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

.... as well as structural reasons.

BE11:20am

Market Share Losses: HSBC, similar to many incumbent banks, has lost market share in HK. HSBC's loan market share was 23pct in 1H18 vs 27pct in 2005; its deposit market share was 29pct vs 33pct. Previously market share loss has been in corporate banking; looking ahead, we worry about retail banking disruption from Virtual Banks.

BE11:29am

Absolute downside below 140p— We see that as the 12-month price level at which VOD would stop offering positive returns (given DPS). To get there, we assume the following: 8.0x valuation for Germany (a discount to Telenet), Italy at net debt levels of competition; Spain at Masmovil’s EV, we take 20% off AMAP, assume no value for Idea and the Ziggo stake at €500m, rest unchanged. Unlike VOD, none of the benchmarks for Italy and Spain owns extensive tower portfolios (effectively for free in this analysis). Granted VOD has problems and the market is right to question delivery. But we see what is being discounted as excessive: VOD is structurally undervalued and has no structural obstacles to execution (no government stakes, etc.).

We do not expect any other asset disposals could create value until
operational performance is restored. So VOD will need time to address its valuation discount, and that could make it a value trap. Perhaps a less discussed option is to change shareholder returns: management is committed to the dividend but support is clearly not working. On the contrary, share buybacks at these levels could really create value (if dividend is sustainable, then VOD is clearly undervalued).

BE11:38am

Though ams’ 3Q18 sales and earnings beat expectations, their 4Q18 guidance missed expectations on sales slightly, but on margin significantly. On the positive side, free cash flow for 3Q18 was substantially better than expected at -$20.4m vs. JPMe of -$96.3m. They are also now indicating that capex for FY18 is $500m, meaning only $68m of capex is planned in 4Q18; implying that, despite the lower guided 4Q18 EBIT, 4Q18 FCF will also be ahead of market expectations bar major working capital changes. Overall, however, despite the positive indications on cash, the issue on the stock is that they are guiding ~18% margin in the best quarter of the year – Q4 when consensus margin for 2019 is 22%. We agree that they may not have a 2Q18-like revenue collapse in 2Q19, but consensus for 2019 will need to come down significantly possibly to 18%. The company is continuing to guide to 60% CAGR growth in revenue from ’16-’19e; but given the margin weakness, we expect revenue growth will be called into question. If one assumes they can actually do $2.5bn in ‘19 sales at 18% margin that would mean ’19 consensus needs to decline by 17%. The market will, however, be more skeptical of sales growth, and if we were to assume ’19e sales of $2.25bn then there would be a 25% cut to consensus EBIT resulting in ‘19e EPS of $3.88, putting stock on 12.9x ‘19e earnings, which, despite strong revenue growth, means ams is not really as cheap as it looked earlier. If this is the last cut in estimates, then it could be time to buy post the decline likely tomorrow; but the market may not be so forgiving given the extent of the likely ’19e consensus cuts. The issue this stock has faced is not that sales growth disappointed, but that margin expectations for’19e initially then ‘20e have been set very high, meaning market interim margin estimates were way too high.

With our pharma hat on, product liability litigations tend to end up in settlements. At this point it is impossible to estimate the average pay-out per potential case and the time-line to conclusion is also unclear. However large litigations in pharma have settled in the low to mid-single digit billion range even where the number of plaintiffs was in the thousands. We include a mid-single digit billion settlement in our downside scenario (approximately €5 per share).

negative development versus what was expected after 10 October.

Ach. Here's Berenberg.

BE11:57am

● Active customers finished the quarter at 102k, with 38% of revenue
generated by professional clients: Plus500 added 20,684 new customers
in Q3 and as churn sharply reduced to 21%, active customers at the end of
the quarter were broadly flat at 102,043 (-1% qoq). Furthermore, Plus500
doubled the amount of revenue it earned from clients classified as elective
professional, up from 20% at the end of Q2 to 38% at the end of Q3. This is
a similar level to the 40% CMC achieved (on a rolling 12-month basis), but
below the 50% IG Group generated in the three months to August.
● Changes to estimates: For the last quarter of FY 2018E, we assume a
similar run rate to Q3, and this results in a revenue forecast of $673m and
EBITDA of $453m. We also update our forecasts for the outer years to
reflect today’s update which reduces FY 2019E and FY 2020E EBITDA by
11% and 17% respectively.
● Valuation: The valuations of all three listed CFD players have been severely
marked down by the market over the last three months, pricing in cuts to
earnings forecasts caused by the new regulations. We think this is
overdone, and that Plus500 is too cheap at 7.3x FY 2019E earnings, so
reiterate our Buy recommendation.

• Progress in Q3 was worse than we had expected in terms of new customer acquisition at 20,684 (CGf: 25,000). In our view, this does not bode well for forecasts into 2019 and 2020 (we expect 125k new customers in each year, which is materially below consensus).
• Momentum in terms of moving clients to professional status appears slow, with just 8% of EEA clients having "elected" to be EPC at the end of Q3, versus 5% at the end of Q2. Importantly, these clients have "elected" to become professional rather than representing conversions.
• In addition, a 20% reduction in ARPU in Q3 (2 month impact from the ESMA regulations), coupled with a 129% increase in cost of acquisition suggests that consensus forecasts will come under pressure for the next couple of years. Our EPS forecasts are 12% and 29% below consensus in 2019 and 2020, respectively.
• 2018 has benefited from a strong H1 and while revenue in the 3m was -14% YoY, we expect to see upside to consensus expectations for the current year. This does not come as a surprise given the recent tick up in volatility. However, investors should focus on 2019 and beyond, and the signs are already that trading will become more difficult.
• We reiterate our SELL recommendation. The stock trades at 7.7x CY19E EPS rising to 9.4x, and yields 7.8% in CY19.

Since April 24 Italian 10y BTP-Bund spreads have now
widened by 198 bp to 312 bp, which is the largest increase
since the Euro area crisis, when they moved from 120 bp in
April 2011 to 552 bp in November 2011. So far, most Euro
area assets have suffered less than during the Euro area
crisis with the exception of Italian equity indices and banks,
which have sold off more. The EUR has weakened in line
likely contributed (Exhibit 1). Peripheral spreads sensitivity
to BTP spreads has decreased materially YTD and IBEX
volatility has diverged from FTSE MIB (Exhibits 2 and 3).
This suggests more risks are priced into Italian assets
compared to Euro area assets. That said, last week there
was some contagion as Portugal and Spain spreads have
widened alongside Italian ones (Spanish fiscal projections
under review have likely contributed).

According to our rates team, markets were already pricing
a one-notch rating cut and only a low probability of larger
downgrades. So, with the Moody’s decision to leave the
outlook stable and some more conciliatory comments from
Brussels, Italian assets might enjoy some temporary relief.
However, our economists remain cautious and think the
market situation may need to get worse before it gets
better. In our view, European assets remain vulnerable to
continued political risk and a worsening of Italian macro
data. For investors who want to hedge an escalation of
Italy risks and rising contagion, IBEX implied volatility
appears low. The next catalyst could be the S&P rating
decision on Friday, October 26.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Our base case assumes that the Italian government will not backtrack in the short term. The Commission will thus have three options: 1) launching an Excessive Debt Procedure (EDP) and imposing sanctions at the same time; 2) launching an EDP but only threatening to impose sanctions at a later stage or 3) starting the procedure to launch an EDP but not opening it over the coming months. To our minds, unless the Italian government changes tack, options 1) and 2) are the most likely. An EDP may thus be launched by mid-January, with a lower probability before year-end. However, if the government capitulates, even partially, before the budget is adopted, this will fuel the already large political tensions within the coalition, increasing further the risk of the budget not being adopted and the government collapsing.
